Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny deferral of removal reasonable under IRPA?
Application_Facts: Applicants sought deferral of removal due to daughter's medical needs and pending H&C application.
Decision_Outcome: The Officer's decision was reasonable and within acceptable outcomes.
Court_Ruling: Judicial review dismissed; Officer's decision upheld.
Defendant_Behavior: Officer relied on CIC Health Management Branch advice and assessed H&C application as not imminent.
Grounds_for_Claim: Daughter's medical needs, pending H&C application
Legal_Standard: Officers must consider medical accessibility and pending H&C applications but have limited discretion under IRPA.
Assessment_Factor: Medical care accessibility in Mexico, imminence of H&C application
Evidence_Used: CIC Health Management Branch advice, details of pending H&C application
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA provisions on deferral of removal, humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Application_Basis: Medical needs of dependent child, ongoing H&C application
Evidence_Assessed: Medical care options in country of origin, status of H&C application
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA, officers must consider medical accessibility and pending H&C applications but have limited discretion.
Harm_Assessment: Potential hardship due to daughter's medical condition if removed
Cause_Description: Applicants sought deferral of removal due to daughter's medical needs and pending H&C application.
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed Officer's rationale and evidence considered
Evidence_Assessment: Officer assessed availability of medical care in Mexico and relevance of pending H&C application
Decision_Rationale: Medical care deemed accessible in Mexico; H&C application not sufficiently imminent to warrant deferral
